titleStmt.title: M46 [Anon: He has emerged then sufficiently from the undifferentiated voices of birds...]. Holograph fragment, undated. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M46 [Anon: He has emerged then sufficiently from the undifferentiated voices of birds...]. Holograph fragment, undated. 9p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: He has emerged then from the sufficiently from the past forest & from the floods, from the to stand to be seen standing at the threshold of door, looking back, even not [illeg.] in outline; a man with a mastiff, with a garden: He is His name may be ; it may be . There is very little to distinguish him from other people. He has no l particular expression; no we cannot imagine what will he [clings?] to the only chiefly what his eye sees. He makes us fal suppose that the emptiness of England: the scarcity of people; the predominance of individuals. We can count the ships Everything belongs to the . We can count her possessions– a few ships, a few palaces. She is the parliament, press, society, law, order. But the man himself, the individual, has the greatest is cumbered, stiff, constrained, with & still: Not so very long ago, words are still writing is still an expressive, a luxurious art. She does not scribble words are Writing is still an art that requires great ceremony. Their What you make with the pen is separate from what you say with the tongue. Only a few years back, words were written beautifully on in by scribes on parchment; & the leaves when bound up, were chained to the lectern; & only you read & read in great physical discomfort, seats at on ahard bench, in a in in the cold. What the Johns & the Edwards write, even with A And There is And Even now, since there is no vulgar public, even now, Even now when words are printed after the printed book has come into existence there is no common the public is the great public is not the reader, or the paymaster. Before the The written words must pass the the please an a senile man – in the first place – & to it must do the book

p.sup: & the undifferentiated voices of birds & men singing together

div.p: do homage to him, with its flattery, some great had a lady, for the reading public reader is a great nobleman, & the book if it is to succeed must find its way first into the palace, or the park manor where the nobles & the gentry have leisure after the hunting after the [illeg.] management of their [illeg.] & the care of the household to read: which they the ladies stitch, or make their [confections?] and they their played music was they sang; they made words sound to the ear.

p.sup: to pick up a lute, to sing a song they read aloud & to sing the song their [illeg.] [her?] with further

p.s: The human being then who stands at the door, was a all the the the the singer then, the man who has a name, who looks back, who finds himself

div.p:
This still undeveloped figure contains in himself all the
different varieties of writing. He is able looks back – he is an historian. He loves. He is a poet. He records sees his own present against a background. He has most a no past for himself – his no language is still In him then we have the rudiments of all the books that have since been written.

It is the printing press that splits this brings confusion. For It is the printing press that makes writing so so many headed, so many limbed, so incoherent & barbed & streaked, a [mongrel?] with so many different parents that it is requires a whole army of learned people & a perpetual procession of fine tasters, to keep any hold on its manifestations. From the printing press The Presses of & & & [illeg.] – the presses that were printing in copy & [carting?] [illeg.] cheap legible books that anyone cd (could) read, were not nice feeders, They were Anything that could be written cd. (could) be printed and, whereas music & painting any thought, any morality, any record, any discourse – whatever passed through the brain of man, it was whatever he worked to argue out, to pressure, to put on record – all this became printed matter. And there The restraint was in his [illeg.]

in himself alone. He When he was still only , only , he could not put into words he was He cou Much was un inexpressible; much was He perhaps non existent Very They should be [illeg.] the [illeg.] of the printing press can make the writer say what is upon him. Music, & painting were thus exerting their pressure too. half [yield?] to the fascination of the other art. Music makes the old songs limits the poet to write what can be sung. This is why the a [shade?] still shrouds the [nose?] & the eyes & the hands a simple

Unlike the painter or the musician, the writer is exposed to innumerable, outlying, inappropriate, irrelevant solicitations. Why not write the history of your parish? or the life of some Roman Emperor? Or compliment your patron? Why not take part in the [illeg.] of your country? And advise the soul of its dangers? Why not become pamphleter, historian, moralist? – There is the press, ready to accept anything. And as the public becomes more learned, as glass is filled into windows & pillows be replace logs, the public adds its invitation to the writer – It is an inquisitve, active minded public, & it soon duplicates the writer takes hold of , & makes him into the familiar voice, with which talks an easy subject: only a few keep to the old art way: & still persist in giving to words a certain making words into works of art, the author

died round about 1477. It was the printed book with the author's name attached that killed him. After that the audience was separate from the singer. Had With Anon died that part of the song that the audience sang, the voice that filled the pause, supplied the [strain?] & added sometimes a nonsensical chorus.

That [babbling?] child like [illeg.] holy voice, that song at the farmyard door, that alternately [illeg.], obscene, devout singer, who was now & again a great artist, died when the printing press came into existence. In his place we have a man with a name, who lives in a house, & has books a name. He is He He has This most He has books; he has a past Time has drawn its veil Winter is past. Time has drawn

The great house in which is still there: either too big for its surroundings: or they are too small for it It stands in its park island of green still close to the high road. It stands in a green among in the [illeg.] Deer are crowded under the great trees: the grass is flowers surround the walks; the grass swells over the a flag flies from the long roof. Many changes since & the great house, with its conglomeration of shops, & courtyards, & walls & [chimneys?] chimneys, lies at only not far from the among the village & the of litter made in house, the bakers shops & the [illeg.] shops, the looking left out of proportion, so large and a monstrous growth, a little dwarfing them, looks too large for its company In do There is the The great house is still Inside there is the great staircase, leading leads through to the long galleries. The rooms are still kept as if were still the Queen. Here are the ornate hard silver fringed Elizabethan chairs; the great carved tables; the the furniture, the curtains, the flagon the silver goblets. Our The tapest chairs on which they sat are much faded. The chest is

p.sup: as if they expected her coming in [illeg.]
Eth (Elizabeth) the Queen played on that swollen bodied instrument

div.p: & cupboards are as polished as if they were new. And Even the toys & knick knacks have survived intact, and unharmed. There are the very lates the still flowing & no doubt resonant to the fingers is very lute that Elizabeth herself played. The carpets are on the floors. But where are the people? – the fantastically ornate figures, in their starched doublets; in their [illeg.] & pearls? They are were more ephemeral than their possessions. They The great Elizabethan houses – Wilton, Penshurst, Hardwick Hall are uninhabitable remain have no tenants. Compared with Not Across the Park the A The Queen Ann manor house is still is still human, vocal, we can fill it with our men & women: but human life has receded from the [lank?] convoluted shell, the gleaming, the iridescent with its fringes, its [tales?], its gilding, its intricate mouldings, its carved elaborate carved legs, its patterns, its loops & knots & fringes, its Regal and but they shine in the spring sunshine of 1940 but the th it there is a gap between them & ourselves these fantastic nobles hunched on their hard chairs & the 17th [century?], & the [19th?] the their ornateness, their brilliancy the lacquered, the decorated, the teased, the emphatic, the ornate, yet rude, at once so convoluted & ceremonious, & so fresh, so [illeg/], so crude, so animal.

Thus in the Elizabethan great house that the influences that told upon the writer, who has just emerged from medieval anonymity are to be found. Since no The artist, the writer who makes words exactly fit his emotions, is p was has presumably of the same much the same sensibility as now. He was not so specialised, so differentiated. He could hesitate then, on the threshold of the great room. He could There the the eye was stimulated

there was much to stimulate it. There were the crimsons & the greens & the blues of the clothing: the ear was also highly [in the along?] pricked. Books were read aloud. Each word was given the sharpness & substance of the speaking voice And then music – the lords & ladies sang his words; added to their sharpness & substance, lilt, rhythm, melody. And he was and his material, his store of words, were fluid, babbling in his mind, like a as if a fin [pumt?] & flow beneath; making it [illeg.] to a old w English words, new French words, Latin words, all molten, capable offlowing taking any shape, capable of [suffering?] colour, of following the [illeg.]. line, of taking the rhythm of the lute. It was Whether he was to write, or to sing or to paint was an open question. The arts then were indterminate, interwoven. Only A transparent barrier lay between them. What [illeg.] precippated (precipitated) the English senses into words & other [those?] into music or to paint must be have been a toss up. For a moment there is a pause, in the Elizabethan hall, when the artist who [illeg.] stands on the threshold might have some taken any one of the three ways. But then [must?] some [mummers?] came into the courtyard. And It was the stage sealed it – the If there had been no actor, – when singers – might have been a

Historians The historians of course have ransacked the vast old deposits in of written in archives the [libraries & archives?], the titles, the wills the account books; deposited left in libraries & archives they have But all their friction has served only to polish the shell. Shell. Was it They have their labours punctured the shell with their friction tell We Know show that there at some body live that some one once inhabited the shell. We hear know that the Pastons were We know that There were Pastons These were There were the in ; & & in ; but at they fought, they & bantered; they loved; & begot children. But it is a rudimentary life. a life of a life is [dark? deep?] [work?] in the shell. immured in silence; hardly able to lif the shell their the shell is polished; re but it remains a shell; as if it were it is as if were told that a [Irish?] poet called [illeg.] had a tweed suit, six hats, & used a malacca cane when he walked. His meal was cooked on a coal fire, & he had a fox terrier. Thus the house was seen, not the m tenant of the house. Save for & the English might be a dumb race; a race of men a race whose gift was for heraldry, for painting, for music. words a a race who went through the his voice suffered who enjoyed & suffered tacitly; a race of merchants & soldiers & priests; whose lives leave behind them cultivated fields, & stone houses, & cathedrals; but no solid but small The great house is dumb dumb; we have to form we have f Only the [farmhouse?] remains; stiff, ornate; fantastic, [unencumbered?] thus Here & there Here & there, in one of their great houses

at old sat at her table writing dispatches, involved, circuitous, forma dispatches to . the phrasing is as intricate & formal as a state title She She drops into Latin & French. She advises, admonishes, preaches; it is a letter written from the pulpit. Yet the violent, & [private?], & resonant The The sound of the bible is in her ears. She only If she condescends to ment mention strawberries, it is with a scowl & a scold. They are full of a the [illeg.] of their, the danger of the time, written not from a mother to a son, but from a counsellor to a confederate. If she condescends to mention strawberry it is with a [sharpness?] & angularity & warning. And the name of god is always on her lips: "God keep us in the faith & send us health & a care to to please God above all....

The violent, suspicious, intemperate, crossgrained old woman, always [illeg.], always in dread, always in fear that her letters be read by some fox, some pryer or [illeg.]; preaches, admonishes, exhorts.

The Bible is the loa model. The bible, which was the "best seller". And the prose of the bible, cannot lend itself to the secular lives. The prose of the bible is There was no example of for a lay intimate prose style. Writing is still a formal expressive art. Prose is not accommodated does not adhere to the simple, the easy, the natural. It is a garment only to be put on when the mind is in a exact & dignified.
And But Lady [illeg.] [stewed?] The prose style This no
The Elizabethans are violent & infatuated long winded & [illeg.] contorted as people because they took the bible for their model

private letters. They are never simple, easy, genial natural. They are never subtle. They are unshaded. Vi Carnation & snow; ebony & gold, like their furnit – in their prose as stiff as their clothes. Inevitably their become furniture deadens when we [dwell?] when their farthingales & ruffs; we build up we contort, & see only the furniture onl pleats & pearls, the ruffs & the garters in all their

But the The subtle, the [alone?], the artist, who who hesitated on the thres conscious of his plebian birth, hesitated on the threshold of the great room was still He was dependent on his audience. It was He was still therefore unspecialised, undifferentiated His eye was stimulated by the crimsons & golds & greens of his clothing; by the angle & pattern on the ceiling. His ear was the stimulated by sound
Whether he was

Prose is not impossible the [illeg.], the fluctuations are for not yet possible But poetry is possible. The [carnival?], the hunting & the great people, the And so wrote the ; celebrating the real queen; but at a distance from the real that in the world of poetry, almost equally in the word & the eye.
